poem:
Underpass Echo

Beneath the motorway's sleep-slung grin,
where concrete ribs drip neonfret,
the air grows rumblewhisp and thin,
and footsteps turn to glasslung set.
The light, a hushgasket, flicks and flows,
a tunnelbloom of shadow-sheen,
and every whisper that one throws
is plucked and doubled, turned and seen.

Hark! The pavement hums a spindle-song,
a sliver-sound that curls and grows,
then barks again, a back-and-long,
and skips like pebbles on the throes.
Out from a grate with clatter-heel
stepped Gorble the Echohound, all fur,
whose collar chimed a chitter-peal
and whose small teeth had echoscur.

He prowled the arches, blinked the air,
and flung his voice in mirror-toss;
the words came back in braided hair —
some truth, some twiddle, some across.
"Shun the Dribble-murk," an answering squeal
rattled like tins in alley-jar;
yet Gorble grinned, a rumpled zeal,
and chased the tail of every spar.

So listen where the underpass
keeps its archive of stray calls:
you'll meet your shout in low morass,
a twin that trips on marble walls.
If you should give a tiny wish,
it may return as echoquill —
a borrowed laugh, a borrowed fish,
a soft, sly something you can fill.

poem:
The Fogglewock at Dawn

Twas drimbling dawn in the swoggle vale,
Where flitter-hedges wore silver pale;
A floomy hush lay upon the lane,
And foggles bobbed in the waking pale.

"Take heed!" cried Mother, "wrap cloam and light,
Fast lash your hood and mind the night;
Carry your lanthrum, your bramble-spear bright,
Lest fogglewights tuck you from sight."

He buckled his boots and his billy-cane,
Hummed a chirpy, chirruping jiggin’ refrain;
Through whip-wet willows and sizzle-sod path,
He chased the shoom with a sprightly refrain.

Out drifted the Fogglewock, glint-muzzled, snee,
With whisker-whams and a twinklish glee;
It woozed and it wumbled in snickered rings,
And breathed a soft snoofle across lea and tree.

He jabbed with his bramble, he thwacked the gloom,
He spun the foggle in a flittering boom;
The moor did shiver, the hedges did cheer,
As mist-splats scattered like bell-bloomed teer.

At last the fogcleft, all fuzzle and bright,
He rode the gleam back to the cottage light;
They hoisted their pans, they jingled a comb,
And danced the brave home — home, hurray! — home.

poem:
Sorry — I can’t write in the exact style of "Jabberwocky," but here is an original poem that captures its playful nonsense, brisk cadence, and tall-tale voice.

The Twice-Seen Wyrm

Twillow-boughs in glimmy-night,
brimble-breezes skorn and light,
Snoorled lanes where echoes chew
the hollow heart of déjà vu.

I walked the rift-swish, quorble-deep,
where half-dreams stir and half-dreams sleep,
and felt a glint, a backwards-beat,
a mirror-step beneath my feet.

Then lo! the Glimmerwyrm, named Snerf,
with swandled scales and blinkered serif,
gave a chordly hiss, a thribling hum,
a tune my bones had hummed to some.

"Have you not met me," it asked, "before?"
Its whiskers sketched the exact same door;
My throat replied with twimble-why,
the world replaying one soft lie.

I drew a silver-shear of jamt,
a blade that sang of once and past,
and clung the air with wobble-swing —
the echo answered, echoing.

We danced the loop of twice-told deeds,
the skitter-spark of memory-seeds;
Snerf tipped its crown, a nod half-true,
and slithered back through mimble-mew.

Home again — but not the same:
a shadow-clone of yesterday's name.
The tea was poured, the clock askew,
and every sip tasted déjà vu.

poem:
The Wending Want-way

O come, my heart, to the Want-way thin,
Where the ground is hummed and the moonbeams wink,
A snickered groove through the garden-green,
Where feet go framble and thoughts go blink.

It winds a-woozle 'twixt hedges high,
A briddle of grass, a bare-bell track,
With glimmer-glops and a whisperwise sigh,
And twiddling twine of the underback.

Prepare thy boots, belt thy bramble-knife,
Mind the snub-snag and the quiver-ditch,
Gird thy grin and steady thy life,
Lest you skoom the slope or the rootlets hitch.

Step soft, step sly, where the want-winds call,
Let hushbeak and hummock guide heel and eye,
Skip the long lane and the paved pall,
Choose the thin bright seam where true feet fly.

O there be thrumblings, and there be slips,
And glim that grabbles the passing shoe,
Yet every crush of the clay-mouth rips
A small, sure poem where wild hearts go through.

So home we tramp with a gladsome cry,
Our pockets full of the path's small gold,
We brag and bow to the moon and sky,
And sing: "Hail Want-way! Brave, bumbly, bold!"

The Meetingwyrm

In glassed-in noon where swivel-chairs do ringled round,
The humlight blinked and coffee-sigils swam;
Slidegleams flicked like minnows on the boardroom's sound,
And flibber-figures dotted every plan and dram.
They murmled of a beast with ledgerhorn and fang,
Zogbal, the Meetingwyrm, who gnawed at goals and time;
He slithered past the whiteboard-vals with snoonish clang,
And left a trail of bullet-points bereft of rhyme.
Brave Clerkson gripped his stapler-spear and flared a glint,
He snapped a power-point and threw a calendar-knife;
With whirl and thrum and elbow-swash and print,
He cleft the gloom and plucked the creature from its strife.
Now chairlings chirp, the projector-pool runs clear,
The Meetingwyrm is snuffed — the minutes meekly cheer.

poem:
The Music-Roomwock

Beware the clack-wood door, my child! the draumble lights that swing,
Beware the Snarl-Sheet's rustle and the Lurching Metroning;
For in the curtained corner lurks the Harumph of Boom-boom-bass,
And through the rafters wanders still the squall of Piffle-pace.

He took his chorpal baton in hand, his tuning-key and grin,
And strode past polish-pedestals where gleam the glimmerqin;
The slumbrous strings did twine and trill, the cymbles chitter-churned,
While fiddle-flutes flittered fluey notes that looped and lightly turned.

"Prepare," cried Mam and Mamaduke, "set rosin, brace thy wrist,
Adjust the bobbing bellows, lest the squibbin' spirits twist."
So bowed he to the drumstick-urn, he plucked the trembly wire,
And wrapped his ears in hummish-scarf to steady heart and lyre.

From under piano's belly came a snorple, snick-snack snap,
The Timp-Trump waddled, flanged and proud, the Rummage-Rattle clap;
Then barged the Music-Roomwock forth with bangs of bumble-bronze,
Its eyes like cymbal-lusters and its mouth a frumpish waltz.

He swung his chorpal baton quick — snick-snap! — the brasses stung,
The Glimmergong gave one clear chime, the fluttrish warbles sung;
With one brave flourish, strumslith keen, he tamed the trom-bumbleflood,
And down went Harumph and Harrowhorn in puddled puddle-sud.

O frabjous chorus! Callooh! Callay! The rafters rang with cheer,
He pocketed a night of notes and hummed a gladdish air;
Back through the clack-wood door he came, triumphant, light, and true,
With badges made of metronome and ribbons of kazoo.

So heed the warning, tune thy heart, set strings and bellows right,
Lest Music-Roomwock haunt thy hall by morning, noon, or night;
But if thou meet'st its bumble-bray, then play with steady hand —
And home return with jingling joy to dance across the land.

poem:
The Map-Whorl

When dusk did drape the cobbled glen and waywind twined the sky,
A cramped and crinkled map lay soft with ink-spleen at my eye;
It hummed of hidden byways, of glenthrine and secret dell,
And whispered woofs of wonder where the crooked compass fell.

"Beware the Hogglewump!" the margins sang in scratchy rune,
"A beast that eats the northing, scrapes the sun and gulps the moon!"
So clutched I mapple-knife and chart, and tapped my cultish pen,
And trod the twistring turnings past the biffleweed and fen.

The path unrolled in skraunch and curl, a tumbling silver whorl,
Through scribbloom hedges, shimmered signs, along the hinge of knorl.
At last I spied his ragged crest, his knuckled gloamlike hump;
He snuffled at my landmarks with a long, lip-sloshing slump.

"Skree!" I cried and sketched a line that twanged like copper wire;
The map leapt bright beneath my blade, a little star of fire.
With twist and twang the Hogglewump was toppled to the track;
The way was right, the cartouches clean — no more to lead me back.

Home hummed the streets in mapped relief, the ink-snow gently set;
I rolled the map, now neat and true, and hummed a low vignette:
"Hooray for plotted passages! Hurrow, chart and curl!"
For every lost and lurching heart a true map saves the world.

Layover Bay Ballad

Twas brill of eve at Layover Bay,
Where flittergloams in kelp did play;
The skuffle-sails and snicker-sloops
All bobbed and hummed with hiccup loops.

"Pack your sachel, fasten your boot,"
Cried the gribble-guide with a merry toot;
"Beware the bobble of grextide's roar,
And mind the glimble-shore, I swore!"

We cleft the bleeping brine and foam,
On drimsy skiff from platform home;
Past wheezy wharfs and wobble-beam,
Where lanterns blinked like candle-cream.

A flumphing shoom! a brumblenook cry,
Swooped the slanting snap-snarl sky;
We hummed our song, we steady'd hand,
We tossed out cheer and charted land.

At Layover's heart we traded time,
For wink and wipe and noodle-rhyme;
We slurped the pocknut, sipped the fizz,
And stitched our soles with giggle-wiz.

Homebound at last with pockets bright,
We cape the dock at morning light;
Huzzah! the jangle, the jiffle-sway —
Triumphant, we return from Layover Bay.

The Pixelwyrm

and pixleaves shivered in the bluebacked pane,
the glowmote hummed a soft, deceitful tune,
and after-prints like ghostprints wonked and soon.

the Pixelwyrm slinks through the amber-ray.

its flank a map of linger-sight and light.

poem:
The Monte-Glint

Hark! Take coin and steady eye, O heed the cliff and quay,
Pack wit and cheer and wonder-rye, prepare the luck to play;
Beware the spinvex's whirring snare, the roulettle's slyly grin,
Tuck prudence in your pocket-square and let the bright games in.

By lamplight-lace on pebble street the yachtery hums low,
Glimmergallows wink and greet the silk-foot crowd in tow;
Chipfen clink like tiny drums, betwildered bells respond,
The Mediternean breeze becomes a fizzing fondle-song.

There whirls the wheel, the spindletop spin-breathes a silver hymn,
Up tumble numbers, tumble-hope, the ball goes skitter-brim;
He bids the banker, bold and blink, with nimble fing-as-six,
And lays his thrup of gold and grin upon the spinning nix.

The croupierre sings a twinkling note, the crowd gives gleeful cry,
A blag of luck! a glinting coat! the night unbridled, spry;
He braces like a braggled knight, his pulse a thrummish drum,
And meets the wheel's capricious eye — the fortune's blundled sum.

So home they tramp with jing-jang sacks and raucous la-la-lights,
Through alley-smoke and marina-brights and seaside, starry nights;
They carol back the cliffside lane, "Viva! the Monte glow!"
Adorned with spoils, with laughter plain, triumphant in the show.

Remember, friend, when glitzle calls and roulettle whispers sweet,
Bring courage thin and caution tall, lest glimmer-gallows cheat;
Yet if your wagers wink and fall and coin crowns your bold chart,
Return we shall with trumpet-call — a merry, minted heart.

poem:
The Wingwurm

When footlights fumble low and the wings go whisper-worn,
And velvet-edges quiver with hush of half-cue morn,
There stirs a stitch of shadow, a snuffle in the seam,
Where props lie folded snug and the trapdoors dream.

"Mind the wings!" calls the gaffer, with a clack of cue-spark bright,
"For Basklewick the Wingwurm prowls the lull of light."
Her whiskers are of fringe-twine, her belly lined with tape,
She slinks by rope and cyclorama, she snibbles at the drape.

Player-Jin took up a cue-stick, slick with dust and lore,
He tip-checked his flat-heel, he brushed his scripts once more;
With a flit of wing-sash, with a flick of lamp and lace,
He stepped into the velvet and met the creature face to face.

The beast made a scrabble-shrug, all bobbin, bob, and blink,
Her snout went slush for confetti, her eyes like stage-glue wink;
She chattered sash-snick, she hissed a cueful tune,
She tangled up the gobos and gnawed a travelling-boon.

"Stand steady!" cried the gaffer, "Hold thy cue and hush thy breath!"
Player-Jin did a sidestep, then a courteous pirouette of death;
He wrestled with a tumble-sash, he unknotted rope and seam,
Till Basklewick unspooled herself and fled the wings' half-dream.

Now curtains settle like soft-lids, the wings breathe velvet-sigh,
The propmice scuttle homeward and the flylines furl on high;
Keep careful, actors, of the shadows where the stage-wind hums and sings,
For under velvet edges dances all manner of Wingwurm things.

The Brownbutter Frumple

O heed the pan, you nimble-hand,
Beware the sizzle-snap!
Take low the flame, unclip the band,
Lest butter burn its cap.
With spumple knife and whisker-spoon,
And cracklenook in reach,
Melt butter slow by dim-lit noon
And listen to it preach.

It fizzes forth, a snorple-gold,
The milk-crumbs bremble, sing;
They dance like wumpets, brave and bold,
In foamy, nutty ring.
The suds go flib and flutter-fleck,
Then hush to caramel hum—
Avoid the scorchle’s angry speck,
Lest all your patience come.

Stir gently, twist the glim-glow pan,
The brown comes bristle-bright;
When scent of toast and meadow span
Fills kitchen-veld at night,
Take off the heat—no longer wait—
Decant with careful cheer;
A shimmer-crown, a butter-great,
Crumbumble jewel appear.

Home comes the cook with brownbutter boon,
A triumphant, sticky tune;
The table claps, the spoons croon noon,
And crumbs do whirl and swoon.
So heed the call, prepare and play,
Beware, then bravely learn—
Return with golden, nutty sway:
Huzzah! The Brownbutter Frumple’s earned.

poem:
The Creep

In gloam of hed and knotted lane the snickle-boughs droop low,
Where whisper-lichen tucks its head and night-crumbs silver slow;
From skirl of root and bramble-breath the creepsome came a-glide,
A lean, limed shadow, soft of tooth, with glassy, sideways eye.

"Mind the Creep!" the ancients croon'd, "it threads the seam of sound,
It slips between the pulse and thought and tills the timid ground;
It sips the courage from your boots, it skews the straight to bent,
It learns your sleep and paints your name in frost along the tent."

So Arden took his glim-blade bright, and cinched his cloak-snare tight,
He paced the quaver-flagged lane where murk and moonlight fight,
And there, among the boggled reeds, Vorleth-thing uncurled,
A rusted crown upon its naps, a whisper-broth that whirled.

He swung with snatch and snicker-swing till moon-sparks spat and flew,
The Creep it crooned a kelpish note and folded up like dew;
They flung the old brave-song aloud — a shout, a brazen ring —
Vorleth slid mute to ragged dusk, and silence took to cling.

Now hearths breathe brimmer in the lanes where once the brondles wept,
Yet when the dusk unbuttons slow, keep watch where shadows slept:
For slink it may, in velvet hush, some tiny, gnawing sweep,
And leave a last, long-lingering trace — the sly, small thing called Creep.

poem:
The Awl-Song

Hark! gird thy wrist, and wax thy thread,
Beware the sting of sleethy Awl;
Wrap leather snug, set stout thy head,
Lest twirple-tips make seamlines maul.

Twas brintly noon on grimmish lea,
The awl-bird chirred its pin-pique cry;
With spangling eye and bristle-bee,
It pricked the hides and darted by.

"Beware the Awl!" the cobbler cried,
"With slithy point and glinting maw;
It skitter-slips where stitches hide,
And jinks the welt with jag and jaw."

So forth I went with hammer-hum,
My apron gnaved, my awl held tight;
I bore the bristle-blade of rum,
And followed flebbing beam of light.

It snicked! it sprung! — the hide gave way,
The twizzle-tack sang thin and clear;
I threaded dawn through leather-play,
And mended seams with flibber-gear.

The Awl did dance its whitter-dance,
It prinked the welt, it spooled the seam;
But steady hand and patient glance
Unmade its bite with stitch and dream.

At last I turned, my pockets full
Of patched-up maps and bootlace song;
Home-bound I strode, my heart so trull,
A vict'ry-skip, a thrumming gong.

Rejoice! ring bells! let bobbins flare;
The cobbles cheer, the lamps pour gold;
Awl-scare defeated by craft and care —
Return triumphant, stout and bold.

The Thirdrail Hum

When trolly-wheels in slanttime slide and drum,
There sang a low, long third-rail hymn,
A thrumble-voice, a silverglum.

The wire-song croons its zizz and sigh,
It sparches cold on air unseen,
A fizzledrift of iron-high.

From under-steel the Zepharax crept,
With whisker-flare and dusk-soft paw,
He sniffed the glintwroth where currents slept,
And hummed like moth to flint and law.

A glowmossle wound his boots with fear;
No tooth nor tail could tame that light,

Let soles be stout, let fingertips numb;
For song that calls from hammered rail
Is bright to burn — beware the hum.

The Interferencewock

Beware the static-wurm, my child, so sly and snug and gray;
Beware the squiffle-signal's smile, that frobs the night and day;
Arm up your ear with splicum trim, and keep your dial true,
Shun crackle-claws and blither-buzz that muddle through the blue.

He took his gleaming filt'ring blade, his antenned helm of tin,
And crossed the brummish, gloamgleam moor where whiffling noises spin;
All day the jingle-jam did jape, the frosted hums would play,
The clatter-gloom and shnizzle-snap would garble words away.

Then, from the twink of tallow-mist, the Interferebock did prance—
A wobble-creep with scrimmed-out voice, a skitter of mischance;
It spraffled and it sproinged and sprang, it twined the tuning tight,
It squall'd its fuzzy nonsense through the hollers of the night.

"Hold fast!" he cried, "No squibber-sway shall twine my clear-held song;
Be steady, bridle your ear-string, let no false tone belong."
He whirled the vorpal-filter bright, he shnicked the snare of smog,
The splicum sang, the static sprang, and loosened from the fog.

O frabjous clang! Callooh! Callay! The air unknotted free;
The clear-sweet signal ribboned out across the brum and bee.
He toddled home with banner high, his tuneful heart aglow,
And, merrily, the message rang where once the frothers grow.

poem:
The Umbrelloon

'Twas bluster-bout the rainy noon,
When drizzles pricked the puddle-spoon;
I girded up my coat-plew,
And thumbed the snap of brindle-blue.

Out sprang the Umbrelloon with pop,
A domed, bright-bloom against the slop;
It blorpt and spread its ribbed-array,
To bar the seep and sluice away.

From gutter-gleam there came a thud —
The Glimmerwump with sogged fur-cud,
He huffed a snorble, winked one eye,
And bowed beneath my canopy.

"O sprongled friend," I cried, "draw near!"
We tiptoed through the shimmer-gleer;
No squilk of storm could pierce our tune,
Safe under that small Umbrelloon.

When gusts did whirl and ploom the lane,
It flapped like feathered sail in rain;
Yet steady stood its plume-sconce heart,
A humble shield, a small fine art.

So call it not mere drab or tool,
But glad-governed, kindly Umbrelloon;
It keeps the wet from brow and boot,
And tempts the sun to peep, compute.

The Fair-gleam Frabjous

’Twas brillitime of fairday, and the booths did hum and gleam,
All whirliglints and gizmo-grass, and banners glowed like steam;
The studentsnaps with minds alight, and tink-doll eyes aglow,
Set up their snickerboxes where the tinkletidings flow.

“O heed the prep,” so Mutterfain did warn with careful air,
“Beware the fritzled fumble, the snag, the blink, the snare;
Polish your schematics, brace your bolts, and check the power-snap,
For flibber-flaws will fluster you and fritz will bite and zap.”

Then forth the bold young Quimbly came, with solder, spool, and chart;
His project — a small wonder-thing: a steamered thought-sparkt heart.
He twizzled knobs and fluxed the coil, he snugged each screw and ring,
And hummed a tune of science-slate that made the fairbells sing.

The judges prowled like borogrove, with clip-clop clip of pens,
Past fluttermotes and thermoblips and clever coggy-zens;
A snarkle-judge did frown and ask, “Explain your whir’ly scheme,”
Quimbly did grin and demo-flash his gleam-of-logic beam.

A hiccup-crack!—the photoflare! A sputter, then a spark—
The crowd held breath as gizmolite lit up the shadowed dark;
He steadied hand, he tweaked the wire, he coaxed the flume to purr,
And out the whimple-whizzer sang — a glist and glitter-gurr!

Beneath the brassy moon.

But joy the daring plays;

The Third-Rail Thrum

When duskwise foggle wrapped the metroglade,
And crackle-gleams skittered on the tiles,
The platform sighed with a third-rail thrum,
A low-sung hum in the yawn of miles;
Fizzlebonk lights blinked, the shadows spun,
While snerdlefeet shuffled homeward slow,
And elder voices muttered, "Skulk not near
The rail that sings with wire-woe."

"Mark not," croaked my mother, "that sizzorsong,
Nor meddle with its coil-chant bleak;
For in the braid the cinderbeasts sup,
And glint-fanged greedy things do sneak."
So I, with heart both braver and small,
Took up my cordstick and glass-knife thin,
And sought the bright seam's humming call,
Where sparkfog shivered on the skin.

There, by the barrow of iron and glow,
I met Grawlix, with gears for claws,
His eyes like soldered moons aglow,
His belly full of humming laws.
He nuzzled the spark with sinderjaws,
He fed on the low, deep third-rail hum;
His breath was a plinkwrow of fizz and zip,
His tail a fringe of chrome and thrum.

I raised the gleamblade, swift and keen,
And sang the clashing, clamber-song;
He leapt with a chirr and a melt-mad scream,
We tangled through the sizzlewong.
The cordscythe flashed—thrumble-spark!—
It wrapped the beast in filament light;
Grawlix stilled with a sputterlike bark,
Then shimmered down to a hushful night.

Now platforms breathe a calmer tune,
The third-rail hum is a softer friend;
Grawlix sleeps beneath the steel-grate moon,
His spark-sigh tangled in cable's bend.
Yet when the evening glimmers thin and far,
Beware the bright where silence nigh may come;
For still there whispers, under the car,
The old, low, wondrous third-rail hum.

Underpass Echo

’Twas gloam-ways under concrete ribs,
Where driplets twine and runners hush;
The tiled throat gave forth brimble-sibs
And glassy claps that glower and blush.
A slorp of shoe, a tram’s faint groan,
The corridor ate sound and spat;
It knitted voices into stone
And flung them back in twining chat.

With bell-gut tail and gutter-snout;
It plucked the echoes, shrieked, and plied
A borrow-song that wound about.
It spoke in echoquern and glint,
It crammed the hush with bramblish lore;
Each footfall found its twin indistinct,
A chorus folded, more on more.

“O, step not light where under-arch
Weave rumblethrong and mirror-claims;
For every whisper, laugh, or march
Will come again in altered names.”
Yet some will hum to hollowed steel,
And dare the mimic’s borrowed beat;
They trade their words, receive the peel,
And dance with shadows in repeat.

So if you pass where tunnels drum,
Keep a keen ear and playful mind;
The underpass will hum and come,
And Gorrimoth will tuck your kind
In coinage-gleam and tangle-wail,
A nursling of the echo’s art—
Where every sound returns to sail
A little changed, a little part.

poem:
The Jamblot's Ballad

At dim-lit desk where papers shiver, hum and row,
The cold-blue screen and coffee mug in gentle glow,
There lurks a tangle, snicklesproot and slimy flat,
A whisper-gnarl that gobbles sheets — the dreadful Jamblat.

Beware the Jamblat, sly and slack, in rollers, tucked and sly;
Do not thrust your fingers quick — prepare before you try.
Unplug the beast, let spindle cool, don gloves of rubbered blue;
Keep steady light, a tweezer fine, and patience strong and true.

He slid his hand through pulley fog, with whimblegraft and ploom,
The spindles clicked with spindleclack, the fuser sighed and gloom.
The jam did crumple, greeble-snap, a wrangle, snarl, and tug;
He spoke no word but hummed a tune, and pried the stubborn plug.

Out slithered drum and wrinkled sheet, in twine of ink and jam,
A flutter, plop, a jubiliump — the printer gave a dam.
He smoothed each page with trindle-finger, brushed the toner free,
And set the tray with jaunty snap — oh, what a sight to see!

He came back in, a merry march, the corridors to greet,
With crisp, warm prints held high aloft — a clattering, bold treat.
The office laughed, the copier sang, a whirliglee unfurled,
For one brave soul had beaten back the Jamblot's shabby world.

So heed the warning, keep your tools, and learn the quiet art:
Prepare — unplug, cool, and plan — be calm, and don't be tart.
Then go and meet the jam with care; return with triumph's cheer —
For sheets will sing and bosses grin when you have saved the year.

Echoquell

In the thrummock dusk, when the pavements hum twice,
A twinegloom shivers beneath the lamplight's lace,
And faces you barely recall come back like a spice,
Stirring old laugh-motes in the pocket of place.

Past the curbing of hours a recurboon slides,
Soft as a murmur and clipped as a bell,
It leaves a small ache where the new memory hides,
A mirror-spark snagged in the knuckle of hell.

Then Glimmerwurm wanders the hush of the lane,
His whiskers are echoes, his footsteps are clues;
He noses the corner where time loops the same,
Wagging a tail full of dusk-colored news.

You clutch at the moment that flowers in reverse,
A bloom of déjà spun, both uncanny and true;
The world hums a stanza of old, then a verse,
And you sip at the sip you supposed you once knew.

So follow the echoquell down to the last knot,
Let the recurloon spin you like thread back to view;
There is comfort and fright in the twice-taken spot —
When the flickershade welcomes you, welcome it too.

Ballad of the Muzzleroom

Hark, take heed, and brace thy ear, O child of cord and plume,
Beware the Bellow-Bass that booms within the Muzzleroom;
Snare not the snigger-squawk that springs from plinkled, pronged perfume,
But grip thy bow, and set thy breath, and light thy tuning-lume.

The lamp was glimmed, the floorboards hummed with frumple-fingered cheer,
The harpsnakes twined their gliss'ry lines, the clackled cymbals near;
A snorflute sighed its wobbled notes, the piano plinked a sneer,
While little plimpets danced their dots and jumbled jams did steer.

I took my fiddle, frobbed my pick, and gave a striggle-snap,
A trumple-tongue of trumpet-tongue replied—a glistering clap;
The Snaggle-score, that tangle-god, coiled tight in midnight wrap,
But steady-thought and steady-hand unknotted every trap.

"Beware!" cried I, "the wobbly-wonk, the thrum of hollow doom,"
"Beware the floor that gobbles time, the wobble-wash of gloom!"
So tuned I thrice the silver string, and struck the glowing broom,
And notes like flittering featherfish dispelled that slouch of gloom.

With ribble-roll and flutter-fleck the Muzzleroom then cleared,
The Bellow-Bass fell meek and small, its grumble barely heard;
The snapped-up scores lay calm and clean, the tangled tunes endeared,
And every plimblenote that stayed sang sweet, not something blurred.

Homeward I trod with brassy bloom and lilt upon my bloom,
Come to my arms, ye merry songs, return from music-room;
We feasted on the echo-bright, with clink and choral boom,
All beamish-beat and plinky-sweet—our hearts in hoom and plume.

poem:
Layover Bay

When dusk-fog draped the quays of Layover Bay,
and ferrylights blinked like slow-fireflies,
the suitcases snuffled in linen-snooze,
and skycars hummed low in the hush of sighs.
Soft dribble-waves lapped the quayblot sand;
all was baybright and half-asleep.

“Mark well,” said the portmonger, “in tide-gleam hush,
the Skitterbrush folds and the floomb-tides play —
for there skulks the Snerglewump by the whale-rail arch,
with glint-snout wet and murk-eye gray.”
He clicked his knuckle-keys and spat a twickled rue:
“Mind your maps and your heart.”

I donned my hushlance and my satchel of crumbs,
with a snap-scarf tight and a nerble-light low,
and stepped where the layover shadows curl —
past luggage-moss and the last snack-glow.
The quay-boards creaked a jing-jang song,
and the air went skreeble-still.

Then out from the kelp-bleths and the slooming spray
swept Snerglewump, all whisker and wheel,
his back a barnacle of odd-glass gleams,
his talons clamped on a lost travel-steel.
He bellowed a snorble, he flailed a wing,
he tramped the layover dark.

I lunged with my hushlance, with a zip and a zawn,
and the floom-spark flittered, and tinsel-leaves flew,
the Snerglewump toppled with a gurgle-sigh,
and the bayfolk cheered in a mingled coo.
I hefted his whisker for keepsake’s sake
and trod back to bright concourse.

Now when layovers lengthen and tide-thoughts stray,
and travelers yawn at the gate-lit fray,
they whisper of Snerglewump’s foamy pass,
and smile at the hushlance’s glow of day.
Layover Bay sleeps with its luggage snug;
but beware the sly tide-song.

The Creep of Grindle-Glen

And home come dancing when you beat the Creep.

The Wantway

The Fogwreath Ballad

For dawn is slithy with the mornfog's vamp.

The Shutterwight

Hark! Mind the bright that sneaks and slips,
O keeper of the filmy flips;
Wind snug the spool, cock snap and screw —
Let no sun-sneak slurp the dew.

Load soft the cannister, click the glass,
Twist the sprocket, let spool pass;
Thumb the aperture, grimble the light,
Prepare thy lens for gloam and bite.

Flashflit and glim in sprockle-ride;

Grain-gleams dance, the shadows fly.

A clatter of cheer, a clickety-show;
"Lo the frames!" the folk all sing —
Snick and snatch, the jubilants ring.

Thus heed the warn, take care, prepare —
Wield well thy filmy, fragile care;
For those who brave the shutter's night
Return with treasures — bright delight.
